717178f-a.title: Manhattan: Broadway - Vesey Street
717178f-a.text:
Broadway, west side, from Vesey Street (left) to
Park Place (right), as viewed across City Hall Park,
from the Municipal Building. In the center is Barclay
Street. This separates the Transportation Building
from the dominant Woolworth Building. Vesey Street
performs this function for the vague St. Paul Chapel
and the Astor Building.
April 1940
George D. Chinn
NO REPRODUCTIONS

717114f-a.title: Manhattan: Broadway - Vesey Street
717114f-a.text:
Broadway, west side, south from Vesey to Fulton Streets. Shown at
this location is St. Paul's P.E. Chapel and grounds.
1936.
W.P.A. Photo.
Federal Writers Project.
CREDIT LINE IMPERATIVE ON ALL REPRODUCTIONS.

717139f-a.title: Manhattan: Broadway - Vesey Street
717139f-a.text:
Broadway, west side, from Vesey to Barclay Street's,
showing the old Astor House, as photographed from the
St. Paul Building.
About 1895

717120f-a.title: Manhattan: Broadway - Vesey Street
717120f-a.text:
Broadway, west side, at Vesey Street, as viewed southwestward on
Park Row and showing St. Pauls P.E. Chapel and a portion of the old
Astor House. Across the nave of the Chapel appears buildings that line
the south side of Fulton Street, west from Broadway to Church Street. Note
the horse drawn cars in the foreground,a junction point of several lines.
About 1891.
Brown Brothers.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.

722433f-a.title: Manhattan: Park Row - Ann Street
722433f-a.text:
Park Row, east side, north from but not including Ann, to and
including Beekman Streets. A portion of the General Post Office is
seen in the left foreground.
About 1923. w .ww N.
Edwin evick.
Cift of E. M. Jenks.

723780f.title: Manhattan: Vesey Street - Broadway
723780f.text:
.12 to 30 Vesey Street, north side, west from, but not including
Broadway (right), to Church Street (left).
June 1926.
Brown Bros.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.

717147f-a.title: Manhattan: Broadway - Vesey Street
717147f-a.text:
Broadway, west side, north from Vesey (left) to Barclay (right)
Streets, showing the Astor House, built in 1832 and opened in 1836
by Boyden, a hotel keeper from Boston. It was reopened September
1, 1875 by F.J. Allan and A.J. Dunn. The portion at the N.W. corner
of Vesey Street was demolished and is today (1937) the site of the
Astor Building, No. 217 Broadway. On this site in 1780 there was an
encampment of Negro slaves, enticed by Lord Dunmore from Virginia.
Large numbers died from small pox and were buried in the ground later
occupied by Stewarts (Department Store) at Chambers Street and Broadway.
Date---f
Eugane L. Armbruster Collection.
MAY BE REPRODUCED.
(2)
The same, at a later date and showing a more extensive view to and
including Park Place. Note the portion of the Astor House still standing.
This was taken down in March 1926 and there upon was erected the 44-
Ntorv Transportation Bcilding, No. 225 Broadway, at the S.W. corner of
Barclay Street. The Woolworth Building occupies the block between Barely
Street and Park Place.
May 1924.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
MAY BE REPRODUCED.

717103f-a.title: Manhattan: Broadway - Vesey Street
717103f-a.text:
(1)
Broadway and Vesey Streets,showing St.Vaul's Church and
Church Ycrd and their modern neighbors.
No Record of Photography.

(2)

717142f-a.text:
Astor House New York
Looking N. up Broadway from Vesey St.

723782f-a.title: Manhattan: Vesey Street - Broadway
723782f-a.text:
Vesey Street, west from Broadway to West Street, showing the U.S.
Post office (white building) and beyond, the N.Y. Telephone Building.
A portion of St. Pauls (P.E.) Cemetery is seen on the south side of the
street, extending to Church Street. Also shown are portions of the
Sixth Ave. and Ninth Ave. Elevated Lines running at this point on
Church and Greenwich Streets, respectively.
April 18, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.

717125f-a.title: Manhattan: Broadway - Vesey Street
717125f-a.text:
217 Broadway, at the N.W. corner of Vesey Sbreet, showing the Astor House
Building, a structure that replaced the southern portion of the old Astor
House.
About 1924
Ehnickerbocker Photo Service
MAY BE REPRODUCED

717137f.title: Manhattan: Broadway - Vesey Street
717137f.text:
Broadway, west side, north from Vesey Street, suow-
ing prominently the old Astor House, built 1832, occupy-
ing the entire block frontage to Barclay Street. Early
records inform us that this site was an encampment for
negro slaves in 1780. Numbers of these died of smallpox
and were buried where the Sun (formerly A. T. Stewart)
Building stands at the N. E. corner of Broadway and
Chambers Street. The Woolworth Building was erected in
1912 and the Transportation Building in 1926. The latter
at the far corner, while the former in the block above.
About 1890
Thru New York Historical
MAY BE PEPRODUCED

717111f-b.title: Manhattan: Broadway - Vesey Street
717111f-b.text:

showing St. Pauls P.E. Chapel as viewed southwestward on Park Row (fore-
ground). This is a set of 3 views; 1 and 2 being similar, while No. 3
is in a northwestward direction from Fulton Street.
September 25, 1927.
Views 2 \& 3:eJune 4, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.

717133f-a.title: Manhattan: Broadway - Vesey Street
717133f-a.text:
Broadway, west side, from Vesey to Barclay Streets,
showing the Astor House (erected in 1832). The view
is southward from Barclay Street. The foreground half
of this building site will be improved with the 44story
Transportation Building in 1926.
May 9, 1913
H. N. Tiemann, photo
Gift of Urbrock Collection
CREDIT LINE IMPERATIVE

717140f-a.title: Manhattan: Broadway - Vesey Street
717140f-a.text:
Broadway, north from Vesey Street(left, not shown).
Detailed from left to right are, the Astor Pouse, the
Postal Telegraph and the Home Life Insurance Co. Bldgs.,
the Thoe Leather 3ank, the Sun Bldg. (formerly A. T.
Stewarts) and the old U. S. General Post Office. The
latter is at the apex formed by the convergence of Park
Row with Broadway at this point. This photo is an enlarge-
ment from an original lantern slide.
About 1895-7
Gift of Russell Freeman
New York Public Library
CREDIT LINE IIPERATIVE

1508007.title: Park Row #15 - Ann Street - Beekman Street
1508007.folder: Park Row #15 - Ann Street - Beekman Street, Manhattan, NY

717149f.title: Manhattan: Broadway - Vesey Street
717149f.text:
Broadway, at the N. W. corner of Vesey Street, showing the
southerly half of the old Astor House demolished. A new 7-story
Astor Building was erected here. The remaining half will sub-
sequently be removed for the 44-storied Transportation Building.
Beyond is the base of the Woolworth Building. On the right appears
the old Post Office. This is at the anex of Cty Hall Park that
is formed by the convergence of Park Row at Broadway. In 1939
this structure was removed and the park restored to its original
form.
November 1, 1913
Gift of Urbrock Collection
MAY 3E REPRODUCED

717121f-a.title: Manhattan: Broadway - Vesey Street
717121f-a.text:
Broadway, south from Vesey (right) and Ann (left) Streets, showing
prominently the Western Union Building and the spire of Trinity Church.
In the right foreground is a portion of the Astor House, facing St. Pauls
Chapel. On the extreme left appears the entrance to the New (ork
Herald Building.
1880.
Brown Brothers.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.

717148f-a.title: Manhattan: Broadway - Vesey Street
717148f-a.text:
Broacway, north from near Vesey Street, showing more of the
west side of the thoroughfare, On the extreme left is part
of the old Astor House. The block front just north of it
was repraced later with the Woolworth Building.
MAY BE REPPODCED  about 1900

220 Broadway, at the S. E. corner of Ann Street, showing the
lower portions of the 25 story St. Paul Building. On the rtght
is a partial view of the National Park Bank, lying between Ann
and Fulton Street's.
About 1930
American Studio, photo
Gift of Urbrock Collection

717132f-a.title: Manhattan: Broadway - Vesey Street
717132f-a.text:
Broadway, west side, south from and including Vesey, to and including
Dey Streets, showimg.a portion of the Astor House, St. Pauls P.E. Chapel
and the Western Union Building. On the extreme left appears a portion
of the New York Herald Building (part of present site of St. Paul
Building).
About 1880.
MAY BE REPRODUCED.

717110f-a.text:

Park Bank. These structures are on opposing sides of this thru-fare.
General Electric Company  1924

717122f-a.title: Manhattan: Broadway - Vesey Street
717122f-a.text:
Broadway, south from Vesey (right) and Ann (left) Streets, showing
prominently the Western Union Building and the spire of Trinity Church.
On the right (foreground) appears a portion of the old Astor House

1509061-a.title: Broadway - Vesey Street - Chambers Street
1509061-a.folder: Broadway - Vesey Street - Chambers Street, Manhattan, NY

723781f-a.title: Manhattan: Vesey Street - Broadway
723781f-a.text:
A general view westward on Vesey Street from Broadway, as seen from
the St. Paul Building (Broadway at the S.E. corner of Ann Street) and
showing the spire of St. Pauls P.E. Chapel silhouetted against the
cemetery and frinity offices at its rear. Prominently shown is the
New York Telephone Co. Building (West Street) of which appears the
Washington Street side. Dimly observable is the New Jersey shore as
seen across the Hudson (North) River. Note the five story loft buildings
standing between the Sixth Ave. (Church Street) and Ninth Ave. (Greenwich
Street) elevated and overshadowed by the Underwood Building. Today (1937)
the downtown United States Post Office rises on this site.
September 1926.
Brown Brothers.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.

717141f-a.title: Manhattan: Broadway - Vesey Street
717141f-a.text:
Broadway, west side, from Vesey to Barclay Streets,
showing the old Astor House, erected in 1832. The far
corner of this site will be utilized for the 44 story
Transportation Building in 1926. In 1912 in the block
above will rise the towering Woolworth Building. At the
right margin appears a glimpse of this site.
About 1900
International News Service
Gift of Urbrock Collection
REPRODUCTION RITBTE UNENDwN

717147f-b.title: Manhattan: Broadway - Vesey Street
717147f-b.text:
Broadway, west side, north from Vesey (left) to Barclay (right)
Streets, showing the Astor House, built in 1832 and opened in 1836
by Boyden, a hotel keeper from Boston. It was reopened September
1, 1875 by F.J. Allan and A.J. Dunn. The portion at the N.W. corner
of Vesey Street was demolished and is today (1937) the site of the
Astor Building, No. 217 Broadway. On this site in 1780 there was an
encampment of Negro slaves, enticed by Lord Dunmore from Virginia.
Large numbers died from small pox and were buried in the ground later
occupied by Stewarts (Department Store) at Chambers Street and Broadway.
Date---f
Eugane L. Armbruster Collection.
MAY BE REPRODUCED.
(2)
The same, at a later date and showing a more extensive view to and
including Park Place. Note the portion of the Astor House still standing.
This was taken down in March 1926 and there upon was erected the 44-
Ntorv Transportation Bcilding, No. 225 Broadway, at the S.W. corner of
Barclay Street. The Woolworth Building occupies the block between Barely
Street and Park Place.
May 1924.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
MAY BE REPRODUCED.

717127f-a.title: Manhattan: Broadway - Ann Street
717127f-a.text:
220 Broadway, at the S. E. corner of Ann Street, showing the
25 storied St. Paul Building. On the left is an eastward view
on Ann Street, from Park Row, an arterial thoroughfare that begins
at this point. Note the ornate National Park Bank at the right.
This is obstructed by a corner of St. Pauls Chapel.
1897
Copyright 1897
C. C. Langill, photo
Gift of Urbrock Collection
REPRODUCTION RICRTE UNENOwN

717146f-a.text:

1913
